bestBHT.bht: In this description of inner struggle, the writer expresses his frustrations and confusion. He desires to do what is right but finds himself unable to fully carry it out. He recognizes that he acts enslaved by the impulses of his carnal nature, and is blinded by sin. This experience of being pulled in two directions is relatable to all believers, who grapple with the tension between their aspirations for righteousness and the lingering effects of their sinful nature. The presence of this conflict emphasizes the ongoing battle between the spirit and the flesh.

Henry Alford: I am in the dark, he says, I am hurried along, I suffer insolence, I am staggered and struck down I know not how.

This desire is not the full determination of the will, the standing with the bow drawn and the arrow aimed; but rather the inclination of the will—the taking up the bow and pointing at the mark, but without power to draw it.
For if the sinner desires not to sin, but to do right, it is plain that what he desires, he does not, and what he desires not, he does.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: In obeying the impulses of my carnal nature I act the slave of another will than my own as a renewed man?
I do not do what I wish, desire, and what I hate, I do.
In obeying the impulses of my carnal nature I act the slave of another will than my own.
Albert Barnes: The prevailing propensity; the habitual fixed inclination of the mind of the Christian, is to do right. The evil course is hated, the right course is loved. This is the characteristic of a pious mind. It distinguishes a holy man from a sinner.
The evil which is done is disapproved; is a source of grief; and the habitual desire of the mind is to avoid it, and be pure. This also distinguishes the Christian from the sinner.

A man who was an infidel before his conversion, and whose mind was filled with scepticism, and cavils, and blasphemy, will find the effect of his former habits of thinking lingering in his mind, and annoying his peace for years.
Marvin Vincent: What I carry out I do not recognize in its true nature, as a slave who ignorantly performs his master's behest without knowing its tendency or result.
Paul says: 'What I carry out I do not recognize in its true nature, as a slave who ignorantly performs his master's behest without knowing its tendency or result.'
When I have acted, I find myself face to face with a result which my moral instinct condemns.
John Calvin: The godly, on the other hand, in whom the regeneration of God is begun, are so divided, that with the chief desire of the heart they aspire to God, seek celestial righteousness, hate sin, and yet they are drawn down to the earth by the relics of their flesh: and thus, while pulled in two ways, they fight against their own nature, and nature fights against them; and they condemn their sins, not only as being constrained by the judgment of reason, but because they really in their hearts abominate them, and on their account loathe themselves.

The pious mind performs not the good it desires to do, because it proceeds not with due activity, and doeth the evil which it would not; for while it desires to stand, it falls, or at least it staggers.

We may hence learn the truth of what we have stated — that Paul speaks here of the faithful, in whom the grace of the Spirit exists, which brings an agreement between the mind and the righteousness of the law; for no hatred of sin is to be found in the flesh.
Philip Schaff: Thus one thing dawns upon him, that he acts in gloomy self-distraction, and in contradiction of a better but helpless desire and repugnance.
The main question here is respecting these two contrasted verbs, 'will' (or, 'wish') and 'hate.'
It suggests that the desire for good is less strong than the hatred of evil.
Archibald T. Robertson: My spiritual perceptions are dulled, blinded by sin.
The dual life pictured here by Paul finds an echo in us all.
There is a deal of controversy as to whether Paul is describing his struggle with sin before conversion or after it.
John Gill: That which I do, I allow not...but of internal lusts, the workings of corruptions in his heart, and which are real actions of the mind, together with the various frailties and infirmities of life.
I do not approve of them, I dislike, abhor, and detest them; I cannot excuse or palliate them, but must condemn them.
He hated vain thoughts, unclean desires, revengeful lusts, the secret motions of all sin in his heart, and the various evil actions of life; which can never be said of an unregenerate man.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Romans 7:15, the writer describes a struggle within himself, torn between his desires to do what is right and his inability to do so. He feels as if he is in the dark, hurried along, and ignorant of the true nature of his actions. Despite his desire to do good, he finds himself face to face with the sinful results of his actions. This inner conflict is characteristic of the dual life that exists within all believers, who, even with the regeneration of God, are divided between their aspiration towards righteousness and the lingering influence of their sinful nature. They condemn their sins not only through reason, but because they genuinely abhor them. Ultimately, this passage highlights the tension between the desires of the Spirit and the remnants of the flesh that believers grapple with in their pursuit of holiness.

In this description of inner struggle, the writer expresses his frustrations and confusion. He desires to do what is right but finds himself unable to fully carry it out. He recognizes that he acts enslaved by the impulses of his carnal nature, and is blinded by sin. This experience of being pulled in two directions is relatable to all believers, who grapple with the tension between their aspirations for righteousness and the lingering effects of their sinful nature. The presence of this conflict emphasizes the ongoing battle between the spirit and the flesh.

In Romans 7:15, the writer describes the internal struggle between their desires and actions. Despite their longing to do what is right, they find themselves stumbling and acting as a slave to their carnal nature. The conflict within them, where they do not do what they wish and do what they hate, resonates with believers who experience a similar dichotomy. This tension between the inclination towards righteousness and the remnants of the flesh is a struggle that believers face in their journey towards holiness.

The writer in this passage describes a struggle within themselves, torn between desires and actions. They acknowledge being in the dark, hurried along, and enslaved by their carnal nature. Despite their longing to do what is right, they find themselves failing to recognize the true nature of their actions. This inner conflict is relatable to all believers, as they grapple with the tension between their aspirations for righteousness and the influence of their sinful nature. It highlights the ongoing battle between the spirit and the flesh.

The writer expresses their struggle in Romans 7:15, as they feel rushed, enslaved, and ignorant of the consequences of their actions. Although desiring to do good, they find themselves unable to carry it out, caught between their inclination towards righteousness and the remnants of their sinful nature. This inner conflict resonates with believers who experience a similar division, fighting against their own nature while condemning their sins and yearning for God's righteousness. It emphasizes the tension between the desires of the spirit and the lingering influence of the flesh.
